communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: SIR ELDON GORST.
div.p: Included in a house party assembled in the Eastern Counties some two-and-twenty years ago was a young man who entered with spirit into all the amusements of a very gay week. There was a county ball in the neighbouring town, besides dancing and amusements of all kinds in the country house itself. Of these gaieties the young man in question was the life and soul. Few of those who formed that house party in the mid-eighties foresaw the eminence to which their fellow-guest would attain, though many were struck with the brilliance of his conversation and the pungency of his wit. One or two predicted for him a great future.

These last were in the right for Eldon Gorst has in these twenty-odd years risen to quite a dazzling height in the service of his country. It was just after the house party in question that he first entered the Foreign Office, at the age of twenty-four. He had, it is true, certain preliminary advantages that stood him in good stead. The son of a distinguished father–for even at that time Sir John Gorst was Solicitor-General, and in the following year he became under-Secretary for India–Eldon Gorst had been educated at Eton, and had gone thence to Trinity College, Cambridge, whence he emerged twentieth wrangler. Yet these are advantages shared by many who elect to make diplomacy their profession. It was this young man's own personality that so soon made its mark, leading him on through the various grades of attaché, third Secretary and second Secretary, until he became, in the year 1890, a very important personage as Controller of Direct Taxes to the Egyptian Government. Here was an opening that gave scope for the brain-power that Nature had given Mr. Eldon Gorst in no scant measure. In two years he became Under-Secretary of State for Finance, and two years later came to him the post of Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior. These important offices brought their holder, of course, into close relations with Lord Cromer, whose understudy he became and that so successfully that five years ago a grateful Government improved plain Mr. Eldon Gorst into Sir Eldon Gorst by bestowing on him a Civil K.C.B. It is only during the present year, however, that the clever young diplomat of twenty years ago attained to the highest reward that comes of long service in Egypt. Lord Cromer, from motives of health and because of advancing years, last spring elected to retire from his responsible position in Cairo. Who so fit to succeed him as Sir Eldon Gorst, trained for so many years under his watchtul eye ? So the man of the moment was there at the moment, and now, at the age of forty-six, finds himselt the deus ex machina of all the complicated network of Egyptian affairs.

Even his most ardent admirers will not be disposed to consider Sir Eldon Gorst particularly imposing in his personal appearance. He is quite unusually short, as the men of these days go, with rather a stoop of the shoulders, and short sight necessitates his wearing pince-nez at all times and seasons. Yet his is an exceedingly clever face, and the eyes, even through their spectacles, have a merry, bright twinkle that shows a keen sense of humonr. In former days no one entered more keenly into the social gaieties of Cairo, and Mr. Gorst, as he then was, in spite of being a man of affairs, managed to be at all the amusing picnic parties, balls, and dinners of the winter season in Egypt. Four years ago, bowever, having waited till he was well over forty, Sir Eldon settled down to matrimony; he wooed and won the daughter of a well-known South African financier, Mr. Charles Rudd, and their wedding in Lancaster Gate was one of the events of the season of 1903. Lady Gorst is a very charming and popular lady, who will do the honours of the British Consulate General with much of the grace that made her predecessor, Lady Cromer, so well liked during these last five seasons at Cairo. To complete the good fortune of Sir Eldon Gorst–to whom, surely, the gods have been extraordinarily kind–there is a young hopeful, who has just accompanied Lady Gorst to Egypt, and will, no doubt, in time carry on the traditions of a specially talented family to the third generation.–(From "The World" Egypt Supplement.)

div.head: Government Office Hours.
div.p: The Government office hours during 1908 will be from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

div.head: German Training Ship.
div.p: This morning the German naval training ship, "Freya" entered Alexandria harbour. The usual salutes were given and returned.

div.head: The Thunderbolt at Ramleh.
div.p: The two cooks, of the Hotel Miramare at Fleming, who were hurt by the thunderbolt, which struck that hotel last Saturday, are getting better. All the damage done to the hotel has been repaired.

div.head: Army Medical Inspection.
div.p: Col. J. M. Jones, P. M. O. in Egypt, accompanied by Major Hardy, R.A.M.C., arrived in Alexandria yesterday and is making his annual medical inspection of the camps and barracks of the Army of Occupation here.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and December 5, 1,249,603, tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 694,146 tons were Welsh, 152,045 Newcastle, 181,018 Yorkshire, 95,931 Scotch and 136,463 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,199,558.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: A total of 10 European and 623 native births and 15 European and 337 native deaths are recorded in Cairo for the week ending December 2nd. Infant mortality has increased amongst the natives, no less than 209 out of the total of 337 being of children under the age of five years. The European deaths include five children in the numbers given. Ten deaths were due to diphtheria, two to typhus including one European to typhoid, one to erysipilas, and one to puerperal fever.

div.head: New Egyptian Co.
div.p: A meeting of shareholders of the New Egyptian Company was held on Thursday afternoon at the Cairo headquarters of the International Chamber of Commerce. 23,417 shares were represented. The object of the meeting was to select a committee of shareholders to demand a statement as to the financial position of the Company from its representatives in Cairo and, if necessary, to have recourse to London. Messrs Paul Oziol, Saint Claire Deville and Cohen were chosen.

div.head: Novel Advertising.
div.p: Quite an original form of advertisement display was witnessed last night at the Terminus of the Ramleh line, where by means of limelight, various advertisements interspersed with excellent views were thrown upon a large screen. The position is excellent, facing as its does the Boulevard de Ramleh, but we would warn the Express Publicité, who have adopted this idea, that their enterprise may cause much comment, if not more serious consequences, by the dislocation of traffic through the crowds gathering in the roadway to witness a free show.

div.head: Egypt and American Cotton.
div.p: The "New York American" remarks :"Many persons believe that cotton will go lower, but some of those who believe this are trying to terrify the Southern planters by pointing to Egypt. Egypt has had many chances to raise all the cotton the world needed, but it has never been able to increase its production materially. Improvements for handling the water of the Nile were made some years ago. They did not result in any increase in the cotton crop, although they did produce an immense crop of scandal in London and Alexandria. The United States is secure in its control of the cotton market, but in spite of that cotton seems to be pointing downward simply because a season of economy has settled all over the world.

div.head: Palestine Exploration Fund.
div.p: The quarterly review of the Palestine Exploration Fund contains much matter of great interest to archæologists. In this review Mr. Stewart Macalister, M.A., F.S.A., continues his report on the excavation of Gezer and also contributes an uncompleted translation of a most interesting article on specimens of fellah wit and humour by a certain Yusif Khattar Kina'an. In addition to these Mr. Macalister furnishes a description of a mosaic newly discovered at Jerusalem. Other articles of interest include the Immovable East by Philip J. Baldensperger. The Bedouin of the Sinaitic Peninsula by W.E. Jennings Bramley. Notes on the Geography of Palestine by the Rev. Caleb Hauser, M.A. The Acra of the Greeks by J.M. Tenz. Interesting Coins of Pella and Bittir by Archdeacon Dowling, Haifa. An Ancient Gate East of the Holy Sepulchre Dead Sea Observations by Dr. E. W. Gurney Masterman. Meteorological Observations taken at Tiberiais in the years 1904-1906 by Rasheed Nassar.

div.p: Will be open during Winter. REDUCED PRICES

div.head: CONGO FREE STATE. THE TRANSFER TO BELGIUM.
div.p: The treaty transferring the Congo Free State to Belgium has just been made public and is arousing considerable interest. It is a somewhat ambiguous political document. The annexes, documents and complementary dispositions of the treaty have been kept secret as yet. The correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph” at Brussels says that the treaty has produced a bad effect in well-informed circles there.

div.head: MACEDONIA. JUDICIAL REFORM.
div.p: According it a statement made in "The Times" to-day the Ambassadors of the Powers interested in the Macedonian question are reported to have arrived at a complete harmonious agreement, regarding a scheme for judicial reform in Macedonia. According to this scheme it is stipulated that inspectors be appointed, half of whom are to be Moslems and half Christians. These inspectors will be ordered to report to the Financial Commission. It is also stipulated that a European jurist should be nominated to a seat on the Commission as a legal expert.

div.head: EGYPT'S DANGER
div.p: Two interesting speeches, representing the different points of view in regard to the policy to be pursued in regard to this country, were made last week. The standpoint of the cosmopolitan European financier is tersely expressed in the statement as to the situation in Egypt made by Baron G. de Reuter, who presided over the second ordinary meeting of the Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt. The official report of his speech was published in our issue of yesterday, but the remarks which we will now quote were not included therein, although considerable prominence is given to them in the London newspapers. The Baron, in moving the adoption of the report, said that during the last twenty-four years the progress of Egypt had been phenomenal from an economical point of view. The position of the fellah had been immensely improved. He wanted to be left alone to cultivate his ground and to be free from the unjust impositions with which he was burdened in the past. The idea that he wanted Parliamentary representation was not serious, and those persons who were really acquainted with the country scoffed at the notion.

"Lord Cromer, at the Guildhall, last month, adverting to this question, stated, that he viewed the extremists in this country who had misled the Egyptians as to the true trend of feeling here as the worst enemies of Egyptian progress : the extremists, were mischievous because of their suggestion of changes for which the state of Egypt was not yet ripe."

If the edifice, which we have built up here, should crumble owing to the policy of the Radical extremists, the Baron pointed out that it was those who had financial interests in this country who would suffer, whether they be foreigners or Egyptians, and he therefore, appealed to the shareholders as business men to do what they could to nip such a danger in the bud. "It was in their power to do it. The extremists in Egypt only existed because they counted upon a certain support in this country and on the Continent; and if that support be denied them they would inevitably and completely cease to exist. All Europeans having a stake in Egypt deplored this fanning of the flame in England, as they deemed it disastrous to all concerned.”

Elsewhere in yesterday's issue we give publicity to an equally characteristic utterance by the very type of person, whose dangerous theories are stigmatised by Baron de Reuter. The lecture on Egypt by the Radical "doctrinaire," Mr. Robertson, M.P., is the expression of a diametrically opposite point of view, which holds financiers as persons of no account in comparison with the realisation of "a priori" theories as to the amelioration of Egypt in accordance with Radical panaceas.

div.head: A CAIRO REVIEW.
div.p: A weekly review is shortly to make its appearance in Cairo. The editor will be Mr. Charles Rudy, the editor of the "Egyptian Standard," who is shortly leaving the service of Mustapha Pasha Kamel for a more congenial occupation of editing a political, social and economic review. It is to be published on or shortly after the beginning of the New Year. The political standpoint of Mr. Rudy's organ will be quite independent. We wish our new contemporary every success and we are sure that its editor will find his new venture far more to his taste than his journalistic association with the Pasha whose treatment of his European employés has aroused universal indignation among all pressmen in Egypt.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL. FRENCH PRESS INDIGNANT.
div.p: The French Press in Cairo of every shade of opinion is unanimous in its condemnation of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's conduct to Mr. Kastner, the late editor of the "Etendard Egyptien." Kamel violated all the principles of professional etiquette and also all the ordinary rules of courtesy by announcing in the "Etendard" that Mr. Kastner had been dismissed, for our French contemporaries declare that this is untrue, as Mr. Kastner sent a letter to Kamel, twenty four hours prior to the alleged dismissal, announcing that he intended severing his connection with Mustapha Pasha Kamel and Company

Our observations on the question would only be interpreted as emanating from a naturally prejudiced source, so we will confine ourselves to quoting the opinion of some Cairo organs, "untainted by Imperialistic prejudice," and we commend the perusal of these comments to Mr. Wilfrid Blunt and the other supporters of Kamel at home.
The Anglophobe "Orient," whose sympathies with Egyptian Nationalism have of late become very pronounced, remarks -

"L'attitude de Moustapha Kamel dans l'incident actuel nous oblige à déclarer que si nous sommes des admirateurs de sa politique, nous ne saurions approuver son attitude comme directeur de journal. L'"Etendard" n'admet pas que les contrères "pleurnichent” sur le cas de notre ami Kastner. Il revendique pour le journaliste la liberté. S'il veut parler de la liberté de traiter ses collaborateurs, aussi cavalièrement, ce n'est plus de la liberté du journaliste qu'il s'agit. Il faut s'entendre."
The "Bourse Egyptienne" says :
"L'opinion unanime de la presse, comme celle du public, sera du côté de notre ami M Kastner.
The "Journal du Caire" remarks: -

"Il nons sera permis de regretter que le départ de M. Kastner ait été annoncé par l'Eterdard" en termes peu courtois. C'est la facheuse façon d'illustrer, par des faits, la théorie du rapprochement entre Egyptiens et Européens. En toute chose, il y a une manière; celle de l'"Etendard" n'est certainement pas la bonne."

"L'Egypte" devotes a considerable space to criticising the conduct of the Pasha, both as regards the Editor of the "Etendard Egyptien" and also in the case of the Editor of the "Egyptian Standard." We extract the following passage from the leading article in to-day's issue of that newspaper :

Ce qu'il y a de particulièrement grave clans les décisions du pacha, c'est qu'elles sont froidement calculées. Elles ont pour but de creuser davantage si possible le fossé profond qui, grâce aux gens de son espèce, rend tout rapprochement impossible entre Egyptiens et étrangers. Mustapha Kamel ne veut pas tenir compte de l'immense sacrifice moral consenti à son soi-disant patriotisme par ceux qui eurent le courage de le servir. Il engage des journalistes pour l'encenser et les congédie pour se distraire. Il appelle cela la liberté. La liberté ? La liberté de l'injustice sans doute ?

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS. TRIAL OF THE OFFICIALS.
div.p: The successor of Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, as Director General of the Administration of Ports and Lighthouses, will probably arrive in Egypt from England in the course of next month.
The trial of the officials of the Ports and Lights Administration, accused of bribery and corruption, will begin on Monday next, the 9th inst, at the Alexandria Native Criminal Court
Mohamed Bey Said, of the Native Court of Appeal, will preside.

Some local newspapers recently stated that Hassan Bey Mazloum, Assistant Private Secretary to the Financial Adviser had been appointed as successor to Socrates Bey Spiro as Director in the Administration of Ports and Lighthouses. This is incorrect as Hassan Bey Mazloum has been appointed as Chief of the Secretariat in the Central Office of the Administration
No successor has as yet been appointed to the post lately oocupied by Spiro Bey.
To The Editor OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE”

Sir, — In order to prevent any misapprehension on the part of your readers which may be caused by the paragraphs which appeared in the "Egyptian Gazette" yesterday, it may be useful to point out that the enquiry held during the summer at the office of Ports and Lighthouses was instituted by the Head of the Administration on his own initiative in consequence of complaints made against two of his officials by their discharged subordinates. He summoned his Director at Port Said to assist at the enquiry and added a Custom House official, whose place was subsequently taken by a Sub-Director of the Finance Administration.
I am &c.
VERITAS.
Alexandria, December 7.

div.head: CAIRO RIFLE MEETING.
div.p: The annual Army and Navy Rifle meeting will take place on the Abbassia Ranges on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the erd, 4th, 5th and 6th of February, 1908. All communications on the subject should be addressed to the Hon. Secretary, Cairo Rifle Meeting, Abbassia Barracks, Cairo. The Hon. Treasurer and Hon. Secretary is Lieut. Sir W.B. Barttelot, Bart, 3rd Bn. Coldstream Guards.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING. SUPPRESSION OF THE DEPARTMENT.
div.p: The supression – for that is what it amounts to–of the Department of Mines had been rumoured for a considerable time, so that the actual carrying out of this important change has excited less surprise than it might otherwise have done. There still, however, remains an element of wonder at this action of the Government, for when it is considered what a large amount of both time and money has been expended in conducting the preliminary work necessary to the ultimate success of the department, it seems to be a matter for regret that it should have been found necessary to suspend operations just at the time when everything had been put on a sound working basis and the real work of the Department was about to commence.

We understand that the Director in his preliminary report to the Government affirmed that it would not be until the year 1908 that any tangible results could be expected, as in his opinion it would be impossible to carry out the organization of the Department in a less time. Thus it happens that now at the close of 1907, when the station at Edfou stands in perfect readiness for the carrying through of any necessary experiments, and all is ready for the start, the Government has chosen to abolish–or at least practically abolish–the Department altogether.

It may very possibly be that in the opinion of the Government, the country is not yet in a sufficiently advanced position to justify further expenditure on what is, after all, a practically unknown quantity, but surely if this is the case, there must have been a deplorable lack of forethought exercised by those to whom the formation of the Department of Mines was originally due, if the Department was intended only to make the crudest investigations into the mining and geological possibilities of the country, then the expenditure at Edfou was entirely unjustifiable and should have been checked. If however the work, which has been carried on, has been in accordance with the ideas and intentions of the Government, it is more than ever surprising that this time should have been chosen for their sudden alterations in plan.

It would be interesting to know the precise reasons which has prompted the Government to take this drastic action. We believe it to be primarily due to motives of economy, but on the other hand it is an undoubted fact that an oil field of considerable value has already been discovered, marble and sulphur have been found, both of good quality and in presumably workable quantities, and for the development of the pottery industries alone it might have been imagined that a further lease of life would have been allotted to the Department responsible for these discoveries. While it is true that as far as gold is concerned, the results have been somewhat disappointing, it is in only very few countries where gold can be said to be the staple form of mineral wealth. There is gold in Egypt. There are emeralds and rubies also. But because neither are found in extraordinary quantities is no reason why the existence of other minerals should be ignored in the great portion of the country as yet unexplored, and such discoveries as have already been made augurs hopefully for the future. We believe that there are still one or two men of the former Department to be retained to act in their original positions, and it may be that the working is therefore simply to remain in abeyance. In the meanwhile we trust that the money spent in the formation of the Edfou base, and in the accumulation of the necessary details pertaining to it will not prove to be so much money wasted.

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE".

Sir, –In reference to the unfortunate incidents that have of late occurred in regard to Limited Liability Companies registered in London, but whose sphere of operations is in Egypt and whose board of directors is only composed of subjects of foreign Powers, the only remedy is to require the entire board to be composed of British subjects amenable to British Consular juridiction, thus avoiding the interminable delays and technical difficulties of the Mixed Tribunals. An Act of Parliament could be passed for this purpose without any difficulty, as by this time the authorities at home should be aware of the abuse by foreigners in Egypt of the businesslike facilities afforded by the English Law for the formation of companies.
Truly Yours

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY. MR. FLETCHER'S WORK.
div.p: At a meeting of the general committee of the Khedivial Agricultural Society on the 4th inst, Mr. Frederick Fletcher, M.A. (Cantab), B. So (Lond), Principal of Agriculture, Gizeh, was elected a member of the executive committee.

Mr. Fletcher was from 1901 to 1903 lecturer on agriculture at the School of Agriculture, Gizeh, and has returned to that school as successor to Dr. Mackenzie after some four years' valuable and varied experience in India as Deputy Director of Agriculture for the Bombay Presidency. Mr. Fletcher was elected foundation scholar of St. John's College, Cambridge, in natural science, and after taking the B.A. degree he proceed to the agricultural department of the university and obtained the diploma in agriculture. During his two years at the School of Agriculture at Gizeh he commenced breeding experiments with Egyptian cotton, and gave special attention to making a complete collection of the varieties of cotton grown all over the world. Before leaving Egypt be passed the departmental examination in Arabic, and wrote a handbook on "Egyptian Insect Pests." In India Mr. Fletcher's work included the organisation of a department of practical agriculture, and the establishment of experimental farms for cotton growing in various parts of the Bombay Presidency. Mr. Fletcher continued to give attention to the collection of cottons, and a largely illustrated monograph compiled by him on this subject is now being printed by the Government of Bombay. Among other agricultural questions taken up by Mr. Fletcher may be mentioned the introduction of Egyptian cotton into the Indus valley, and an investigation of the so-called "exhaustion" of soils, on which latter subject he prepared a special paper now being printed by the Agricultural Department of the Government of ludia. Mr. Fletcher has been able to see a considerable improvement in the quality of cotton grown in the Bombay Presidency, and he was not infrequently called upon by other provinces to advise on questions connected with cotton and irrigation for Agricultural purposes. His special knowledge of the vast projects of irrigation in the unreclaimed tracts of the Punjab places him in the front rank of authorities in Egypt on so important a subject as land reclamation.

The Ministry of Education and the new Department of Agriculture and Technical Education are to be congratulated upon having secured the services of an agricultural expert and administrator with such wide and important experience, and it may be expected that the School of Agriculture and also the Khedivial Agricultural Society will largely benefit as a result of the appointment of Mr. Fletcher.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT. MONTANA V. ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon and this morning the case of Mr. Montana v. the Anglo-Egyptian Bank was heard at the British Consulate before Judge Cator of the Supreme Consular Court. Counsel for the plaintiff was Mr. Halford assisted by Mr. Moss, the counsel for the defence being Mr. A.W. Preston. Mr. Montana claims a sum of £3,000 (approximately) on the grounds of having instructed on July 3, 1907 the Anglo-Egyptian Bank to pay in London by telegram a sum of £11,016 due on July 16,1907, and that his instructions were not carried out. The amount having been deposited at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Alexandria, the Bank telegraphed the same to their London office, but, it is alleged, neglected to insert in their telegram the fact that the sum mentioned was domiciled at the Bank of Egypt; the complainant thus claims damages on the ground of loss of credit. During yesterday afternoon the witnesses heard were Mr. Ralli, Mr. E. Moss, Mr. Triandas and Mr. G. Morris. The case was adjourned at ten minutes to one this afternoon until 2 p.m.

div.head: MEN-OF-WAR AT PORT SAID.
div.p: H.H.S. "Venus" came out of the Canal on Tuesday night, and will proceed to Sardinia on Sunday morning.

H.M.S. "Diana" will remain at Port Said a few days longer.

div.head: THE CITIES OF THE EGYPTIAN SULTANS
div.p: Residents in Egypt, who are thinking of making Christmas boxes for their friends at home, could not do better than order their booksellers to send them Professor Margoliouth's new book on the cities of the Egyptian Sultans, Cairo, Jerusalem and Damascus. The illustrations in colour by Mr. Water Tyrwhitt give a most vivid and artistic representation of Oriental Cairo and the letter press is as interesting as the pictures are beautiful. It is needless to mention that all the historical details are of extreme accuracy in a work coming from such a polymath as the Laudian Professor of Arabic. Professor Margoliouth, who dedicates the book to the Princess Nazli Hanem, in his preface to the work says that its compilation was "a relief from the labour of editing and translating Arabic texts. The chance of being associated at any time in his life with the fine arts constituted a temptation which he was unable to resist." Messrs Chatto and Windus are the publishers.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL,
div.p: Our telegrams announce the engagement of Prince Ferdinand of Bulgaria to the Princess Eleonora of Reuss. The Princess is the sister of Henry XXIV, Prince of Reuss-Köstritz. She was born at Trebschen in 1860 and is one year older than Prince Ferdinand. His first wife was a Bourbon of the Parma Branch, who died in 1899 at the age of 29.

div.p: The Kansas City National Bank of Commerce has suspended payments. Its liabilities total to 24,000,000 dollars. This was followed by an order from Mr. Cortelyou demanding of all National Banks & statement of their position.

div.head: WEATHER OF NOVEMBER SURVEY DEPARTMENTS REPORT.
div.p: During the first half of the month the weather was fine on the whole but cold. In the second fortnight, however, from the 15th to the 21st. and from the 28th to the end of the month, two depressions passed eastwards along the Mediterranean with consequent bad weather, accompanied by rain over the Delta. Pressure was on the whole above normal, and temperature was below it nearly everywhere in Egypt and and the Sudan.

Except at Port Said where there was a slight defect, rainfall in northern Egypt was much above the usual amount for the month. The Sudan, however, where usually a few showers fall, showed a marked deficiency except at Roseires. At the latter station 33 mm. fell in place of the normal 8.7 mm.
The Nile showed a slight improvement in the Sudan towards the middle of the month, in consequence of the rains in Abyssinia, but afterwards fell away from the mean levels towards the end.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.
There is no change in the weather conditions This morning opens nice and clear with a light N.W. breeze and a steady barometer.

Terrifigales and rains have visited this Island during the last fortaight. Much havoc was caused in many parts by the visitation of a windstorm of unusual fury which broke over the Island uprooting trees, breaking down huge branches, damaging roofs and in various ways causing loss to owners of property. The rain storm of last week was the most severe that Cyprus has known for many years. Floods occurred in a number of localities and losses have resulted to farmers and gardeners both in regard to their crops and their live stook.

The railway too suffered no little damage from the washing away of embankments, and the displacing of sleepers. The passengers by the afternoon train from Nicosia to Famagusta on Friday the 29th, had a series of unpleasant experiences, which luckily terminated so far satisfactorily, inasmuch as they reached the port in time for the weekly mail steamer. It was doubtful until the last moment whether the train would be able to get through, and had it not been for the resourcefulness and energy of Mr. P. P. Higgins, the Superintendent of the Locomotive Department, who himself proceeded up the line and took personal charge of the engine and succeeded in piloting it safely across the most damaged portion of the permanent way, it is improbable that the train would have reached its destination.

Among the passengers were Mr. Justice and Mrs., Miss and Master Leo Parker, who were leaving for England before proceeding to their new home in the Leeward Islands. Mr. Parker had been fêted to an unprecedented extent for some little time before his departure and after seventeen years' service in the Island he must have felt gratified by the many friendly dinners and farewell meetings held in his honour. Not only did his brother officials testify in this manner to their regret at his departure, but also representative members of each section of the community. The dinner given on the 27th by members of the English Club in Nicosia was attended by His Excellency the High Commissioner and was of a specially enthusiastic charaeter. On leaving the club the carriage in which he returned home was drawn for a considerable distance by members of the club.

Some very bad passages have been made lately by the SS. "Salamis" while fulfilling her weekly mail service. Last week the state of the sea would not allow her to take on passengers or cargo at Limassol on her arrival; but as the wind and sea abated she returned to Limassol from Famagusta before crossing back to Port Said. Every week full cargoes of cattle, sheep and pigs are shipped for Egypt, but a very poor time they have of it in bad weather, and the proportion which die en-route cannot be insignificant.
Mr. Stanley Fisher, President of the District Court, Kyrenia, returned from leave last week. Mr. and Mrs. W. Chaplin, of Perapedia, have also arrived back in the Island.

div.head: THE ADVANCE OF ABYSSINIA.
div.p: The decree of the Emperor Menelik announcing the construction of a Cabinet on European lines is as follows -
"The Lion of Judah has prevailed.
" Salutation be to you.
" It is some time since we thought of introducing a European system to our country, You have always indicated (this), and said it would be good if we, too, would adopt some of the European systems.

"I have now taken steps to appoint a Ministry, and, if it is the will of God, I will complete it. I inform you that I have appointed the following persons.-Affa Negus Nasibu, Fitaurari Habta Giorgis, Privy Seal Gabra Selassi, Bejirond Mulagata, Likamaquas Katama, Nagadras Haila Giorgis, Kantiba Walda Sadik."

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: THE WHEAT RIOT
div.p: The recent wheat riot in Beyrout, which resulted in the prohibition of the exportation of wheat, barley and dariseed, was followed by other more moderate demonstrations. On shipments of wheat being stopped the prices naturally fell down further as the wheat merchants feared a recrudescence of the minatory spirit of the mob. The various millers, who own steam-mills and deal at the same time in wheat, naturally resented this manner in which the tables were turned upon them and struck, refusing to grind any wheat on hire and even to sell any of their flour in stock, and the poor public found itself again in the same impasse. It was then that the Municipality interfered officially. Several municipal officials were given a sudden order to seize several of the bread stalls and had the loaves weighed when they found an enormous deficiency in the weight. The breadsellers were of course fined and then a municipal notice was published in the local papers to the effect that in case a seller of wheat was known to have charged more then piastres 4 per two okes of extra flour and corresponding prices for the lower qualities, he would be handed over to the authorities to receive the punishment provided for by the law. This measure did not have its full effect for prices of flour of extra quality continue to range between piastres 5 and 5½.

div.head: The Hedjaz Railway.
div.p: The Hedjaz Railway affords a refutation of the widespread belief in the refractoriness of Turkey to reform and the assimilation of modern methods of administration. The Sovereign has only to keep a vigilant eye and make his subordinates realize the earnestness of the Imperial wish for honest work and energy and the undertaking, however vast it may be, more or less will be properly carried out. The Hedjaz Railway has since its inception been fortunate enough to enlist the constant sympathy of the Sultan and the results have belied the pessimistic predictions that had been made universally about it, even by men of great experience and foresight. Every day we have proofs of the continuation of this vigilant interest on the part of the Imperial head of this colossal undertaking, and this interest acts as a marvellous mainspring of inspiration to a composite body addicted by heredity and habit to the loosest form of administration. And to afford a constant proof and reminder of the Sultan's close interest and earnest wish, the puissant instrumentality of the Press in the Empire is brought to bear on the subject. Every order, action or event touching the "Grand Line” is communicated officially to the different papers for insertion, and the following are some that have recently appeared : –

Some of the Government officials in various departments at the capital have been entrusted with the supplementary duties of lending assistance and exercising control over the financial operations of the railway, and three Moslem sanitary doctors have been added to the staff on the line to treat such of the working soldiers as may succumb to illness. A special Irade has been promulgated enjoining upon these sanitary doctors the discharge of their duties in the most strict and conscientious manner under penalty of severe punishment.

The same Irade includes the ordering of, 3000 cloaks and other wearing apparel for the soldiers working on the line. The Sultan seems to take interest in every detail, and his devotion to this pet scheme may be called paternal.

Another recent Irade grants Meissner Pasha, the capable and indefatigable German engineer and director of the construction works, a monthly allowance of £tq. 50 in addition to his salary. This allowance shall continue to be paid after the Pasha's death to his legal heirs. Every effort is being done to push the work vigorously and reach with the least possible loss of time the terminal parts. A thousand soldiers selected from the Imperial Guard and other regiments have lately been added to the number of soldiers engaged in the embankment works. Some of this increased number is destined to fill the gaps occasioned by the elimination of sick soldiers. The progress indeed is so rapid and the near completion of the line is so sanguinely anticipated that the High Commission at Constantinople already contemplates the ordering of the rolling stock to be employed between Medina and Mecca.

div.head: Medina Improvements.
div.p: A Imperial Irade has been issued for the drawing of the waters of Ain Saffra to Al Medina in iron pipes. This together with the project of the lighting by electricity of the Prophet's Sanctuary at the "Luminous City" constitute a rather bold though commendable departure and a tendency towards a slow breaking of the barrier that has so far jealously guarded the sacred towns, changeless throngh the centuries, in their antique garb of early Islamic traditions pure and intact.

div.head: Motors In Syria.
div.p: A special committee has recently been formed to study and report upon the project of a motor service between Alexandretta and Baghdad with branch routes to Aleppo and Moussaul. The motor cars' capacity is to accomodate sixteen passengers. One cannot help feeling rather sceptical about the ultimate materialization of this scheme for many reasons, the most potent of which is the probable opposition of the Baghdad Railway. Can this be meant as a threat to be used to advantage by the Porte in future difficulties.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

Il est incontestable, et nous ne faisons pas de difficultés pour le reconnaitre, que les honneurs de la semaine reviennent aux haussiers. Il n'y a certainement rien de sérieux et de bien important comme résultat matériel, mais en l'absence de tout appui du dehors, arriver à faire 1/4 de tallari d'avance et après déjà une amélioration précédente, cela constitue un succès, d'autant plus méritoire qu'il a été obtenu à la suite des rachats du découvert, le véritable point qui était visé par les haussiers et qui a fini par justifier leurs espérances

Ce revirement pour le mieux durera-t-il ? La facilité avec laquelle le Janvier vendu par le commerce a été absorbé, dénoterait qu'il y a tonjours un découvert spéculatif assez important, mais tant qu'il n'y a rien de nouveau du dehors pour les seconder, les haussiers auraient tort de précipiter le mouvement et surtout de tomber dans l'exagération, comme d'aucuns ont l'air de vouloir le faire. Les circonstances les aident pour le moment et ils ont parfaite ment raison d'en profiter ; inais leur réussite serait plus sure s'il y mettaient de la mode. ration, surtout que nous ne sommes nullement à bon marché pour nos cotons, relativement aux américains.

Ces quelques mots pourraient être pris pour un indice que nous avons changé d'avis quant à la situation de l'article Il n'en est rien pour le moment, mais si au fond notre sentiment reste pour la baisse, cela ne nous empêche pas, ne fat-ce que comme question de principe, de constater sans parti pris la réalité des choses et cette réalité est que pour cette semaine la fermeté a constamment prédominé et que les moments de faiblesse passagère qui ont été enregistrés n'ont eu d'autres causes que le désir de réaliser

Le revers de la médaille à cela est que le commerce continue à ne se présenter sur le marché que comme vendeur, confirmant de la sorte l'information que nous n'avons fait que soutenir depuis plusieurs semaines, à savoir que la demande manque de la part de la filature; mais si jusqu'ici cela est vrai, il n'en est pas moins positit, d'autre part, que les sollicitations d'offres commencent à devenir plus nombreu ses et plus fréquentes. Cela ne veut pas dire qu'à coup sûr nous allons assister à un prochain réveil de la demande, car la filature pourrait bien continuer à afficher la prétention de vouloir acheter les éloignés aux mêmes cours que le disponible, mais les engagements très moderés de nos exportateurs pour les livraisons à partir de janvier feraient croire à la probabilité de ce réveil.

Toutefois, à notre avis, il ne faut pas s'attendre à des miracles, car par le Continent on commenced employer les bons américains, qui sont abondants, en remplacement de l'égyptien, pour certains articles, et cette circonstance pourrait bien limiter le réveil éventuel de la demande, dont nous venons de parler, aux seules qualités fines. Nous signalons simplement la chose. Quant aux autres atouts en faveur des haussiers, ils consistent anjourd'hui dans la question des exportations et dans celles de la qcalité.

Sur le premier point il n'y a encore aucun signe de diminution marquée pour s'y baser, mais il y a une telle unanimité dans l'assertion que, sauf pouvelles affaires, il y aura réduction dans nos embarquements après la seconde semaine de Décembre, qu'on est bien forcé de croire qu'il y a un fond de vrai dans ce qui se dit. Rappelons à cette occasion que Décembre de l'ann'e dernière a été de 156.000 balles, chiffre qui, pour cette année du moins, semble devoir maintenir le record.

Pour ce qui est de la qualité, nous avons déjà expliqué que le véritable point dur serait pour le consommateur ; mais, pour ce qui est des contrats, la poeition sans être très aisée, serait en tous cas, beaucoup moins grave. Ajoutons encore que vulgairement l'on dit que fante de grives on mange des merles "et, partant, il est à croire que si le bon Mit Affifi devait être rare, on pourrait bien tomber sur le Goodtair et sur les provevances Haute-Egypte pour les besoins indispensables en Egyptiens pour le reste de la campagne. – Ce sont des points aussi à ne pas perdre de vue.

Pour revenir au marché, disons maintenant que la clôture de la semaine aen lien à 1919 32 pour le Janvier et 20 15/32 pour le Mars, que le maximum des cours a été pratique Mercredi et a été de 1923/32 pour le premier mois et 20 19/32 pour le second ; qu'en outro l'activité. malgré quelques accalmies, a été satisfaisante dans son ensemble et que la tendance semble bonne. On s'est occupé un peu plus du Novembre 1908 ; quand même les affaires n'y sont guère nombreuses. Le dernier prix affiché pour cette échéance est de 19 31/32.

L'Alexandria General Produce Association a publié son résumé de Novembre. Au fond il ne vous apprend rien de nouveau et la seule modification consiste dans l'estimation de la récolte qui, au lieu de 6 3/4 à 7 millions de Cantars, est donné maintenant comme étant de 6.750.000'environ Cela n'a l'air de rien, mais en somme l'idée de 6 3/4 minimum semble exclue par cette nouvelle évaluation. Tout le monde n'est pas satisfait et aux entêtés qui tiennent pour 6 1/2 maximum, on peut opposer ceux qui penchent pour les 7 millions et nous somthes du nombre. Toutefois, si nong noye trompons, nous en serons quitte pour reprocher l'erreur à nos amis particuliers qui nous renseignent,

Les nouvelles du dehors ne nous ont pas manqué: Wall Street, dans la crainte d'un mauvais Bureau, continue à acheter, tandis que Price, que l'on dit en train de vendre, donne comme pronostic 12 000.000 Balles. Miss Giles, de son côté, a lancé son estimation de 12.100.000 Batles. La date du 10 n'est pas éloignée et ce jour-là nous serons fixés sur les idées du Bureau

On signale de New York, de source très sérieuse, et contrairement à des assertions spéculatives, que la filature ne montre aucun intérêt au mouvement de hausse actuel et il paraitrait que l'industrie cotonnière aux EtatsUnis a été beaucoup plus touchée qu'on ne le pensait par la crise financière. Mais comme les choses semblent s'arranger sérieusement de ce côté-là, il est à espérer que la filature américaine aussi ne tardera pas à mieux marcher qu'elle ne le fait actuellement.

Ce qui est regrettable seulement, c'est que de New York on ait annoncé un nouveau renchérissement de la prime sur l'or et une nouvelle faillite d'une Bar que avec 24,000,000 de dollars de passif. Certes cela ne signifie pas que les choses vont de nouveau mal, mais on aurait préféré rester sous l'impression que tout était déhnitivement fini du côté des fail. lites.
Par contre, les dépêches nous ont annoncé hier le règlement de la question de la grève à Oldham.
Tant mieux. --- Cette solution favorable ne changera 'en rien l'état des choses, mais, elle évite une crise au coton dont le besoin, d'ailleurs, ne se faisait nullement sentir. .

Notre marché do disponible a été plas actif et d'une façon générale les acheteurs se sont intéressés à toutes les qualités. A signaler cependant le fait que, tandis que les classements supériegrs ont suivi la hausse des contrats, les qualités de fully fair et au-dessous ont baissé et ceci s'applique tout aussi bien au Mit Affifi qu'aux provenances Haute Egypte Ce dernier genre aussi attire un peu plus l'attention des exportateurs.

Quant aux différences relevées de la cote officielle elles consistent en une hausse de 1/4 à 1/2 tallari pour les deux genres suementionnés, tandis que pour les variétés les prix restent sans changeinent pour l'Abassi, en hausse de 1/4 pour le Joannovich et de 1/2 tallari pour le Nubari. .
Les exportations de la semaine ont atteint le chiffre très satisfaisant de 38.000 balles, contre 41.700 pour la même période en 1906.
La semaine prochaine sera forte aussi, quoi. que d'après nous elle restera inférieure à la semaine correspondante de l'année passée qui a été de 43000 balles.
Liverpool a été plus actif pour les égyptiens disponibles, mais sans changement pour le spot qui reste à 10 18.
Les futurs Janvier, par contre, gagnent 7/64 à la cote de 9 61/64.

Les américains aussi ont eu un marché très animé, avec des ventes atteignant jusqu'à 18000 balles, et pour ce qui est des prix, la hausse a consisté en 17 points pour le spot, 15 et 13 pour les futurs, respectivement cotés ce soir à 6.35 pour le premier et 6 pour le janvier février et le mars-avril
Graines de Coton

Les arrivages ont été supérieurs à ceux de l'année dernière et quoique les exportations soient restées dans le cas opposé, les prix n'en ont pas inoins été très fermes, pour finir à P.T. 70 pour le spot.

En contrats, la situation est toujours la même, soit peu d'affaires, mais cours sontenus. La dernière cote est de P.T. 72 1 2 pour le Décembre Janvier et 75 20'40 pour le FévrierMars. Il y a un peu d'élargissement dans le report.

Hull s'était tenu calme pour nos graines, mais depuis hier il y a fermeté et amélioration dans l'article, fait que l'on attribue aux achats de la spéculation. En tous cas, la cote aujourd'hui est de £ 6. 16/3-6.17/6 pour DécembreJanvier
Huiles et tourteaux continuent i être calmes, tandis que Bombay ne signale aucun changement de prix.

div.head: Alexandria General Produce Association
div.p: Section Cotonniere
RÉSUMÉ DES REPONSES REÇUES EN NOVEMBRE 1907

La température en Novembre, à l'exception des derniers dix jours du mois, a été favorable aux cotonniers, mais par suite du peu de coton qui restait à cueillir, les effets de cette circonstance sur le résultut total de la récolte n'ont en que pen d'importance.
La troisième cueillette a été irrégulière : bonne dans quelques districts, son rendement n été médiocre et inêine insignifiant dans les antres.
Le rendement l'igrenage s'est maintenu de 1 à 2 % supérieur à celui de l'année passée.

Ces renseignements sont légèrement moins bons que ceux de fin Octobre et, par consé. quent, nous croyons devoir modifier notre pré. cédente évaluation de la récolte en la mettant à Cantars 6,750,000 environ.

div.head: LA SEMAINE
div.p: L'allure de lundi a été dans l'ensemble très satisfaisante avec un courant d'affaires assez facile et suivi, anns que pourtant elle ait rien présenté de bien saillant à signaler. On était favorablement impressionné par la hausse du coton et la baisse rapide da taux privé d'escompte.

Notre marché a eu le lendemain le même aspect ; les vendeurs s'étant pour la plupart retirés dans l'attente de meilleurs prix, les hauseiers en ont profité pour pousser les cours et ils y ont parfaitement réussi. L'attention s'est concentrée en National Bank, Agricole, Crédit Franco Egyptien, Land Bank, Comptoir, Levico, Helouan et Ordinary Khedivial Mail. Il s'agissait en général de demande sans contre-partie. En definitive les affaires n'ont eu aucune importance relativement aux oscillations de la cote.

Mereredi, après une ouverture bruyante inais pauvre en transactions, leton aperdu de sa fermeté en cours de lance et kon a clature dans un ealme plat. A s'en rapporter à la cote, on aurait pu croire à une activité remarquable; malheureusement, comme nous venons de le constater, les cours étaient en général nominaux, inscrits en fin de séance au milieu d'un tapage assourdissant d'intéressée. En valeurs dirigeantes la tenue a été inégale, l'Agricole et la Delta Light étant fermes, tandis que la National Bank était offerte.

Il est difficile de caractériser le marché d'hier: Les échanges étaient presque aula faute de vendeurs, disait-on, et cependant il se dégageait de l'ensemble un sentiment de lourdeur et de lassitade ; aussi gerait-il plus exact à notre avis de dire que d'un côté les acheteurs, s'ils existent, ne montrent encore que peu d'empressement et que de l'autre les vendeurs de naguère à moitié rassurés par la reprise de ces derniers jours et par la baisse continue du taux d'escompte, attendent de meilleurs prix pour liquider.

Enfin, l'annonce que la Banque d'Angleterre ne réduirait pas son taux d'escompte à cause de la demande d'or américaine a eu ce matin sa répercussion sur notre place où l'on s'attendait généralement à cette réduction, pour aider la reprise. Comme hier la corbeille était morne ; on ne faisait rien ou à peu près, au point qu'une demande ou une offre insignifiantes ont suffi occasionner des oscillations disproportionnées faute de contre-partie. En somme, c'était un marché restreint, sans rien de saillant. Il y a eu pourtant quelques affaires en Agricole, Delta Light, Dafra et Union Foncière. L'Aboukir, qui était demandée sous vendeurs et cela depuis quelques jours, était offerte aujourd'hui. Les valeurs égyptiennes cotées à Paris étaient calmes. Une offre d'Urbaine a ramené le cours de ce titre de 3 7/16 à 3 1/4. Bref, l'ensemble est lourd, at sans tendance bien définie. Nous dépendons plus que jamais de l'étranger dont les nouvel les pour le moment sont plutôt défavorables.

Il a été vendu cette semaine aux enchères publiques 50 Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie a 140 francs, 61 actions Frigorifiques d'Egypte à 2 3/4, 46 actions de capital Eaux du Caire à 97 fr. et 50 a 98, 45 actions nouvelles de jouissance Eaux du Caire à 155 fr. (moins le non-versé) et 404 anciennes, dont 50 à 175 fr., 100 à 175 1/2, 50 à 176 1/2, 100 à 177, 54 à 178 1/2 et 50 à 179, 100 Karam à 16/64.

div.head: FLUCTUATIONS DE LA COTE
div.p: Sur une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites da icote officielle de notre bourse, 29 sont en hausse et 11 seulement en baisse, les autres demeurant stationnaires aux cours antérieurs.

Parmi les fluctuations les plus sensibles, les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie gagnent 8 francs, l'Alexandria Water 5/8, la Deira 9/16, las Nile Land 1/2, la Privilégiée Khedivial Mail 1/4, ainsi que la Land Bank et l'Urbaine, l'Union Foncière et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien 3/16 ; les actions de capital Eaux du Caire reculent de 5 francs, tandis que les parts de jouissance avancent d'une somme égale, les Dividendes Bière du Caire baissent de 6 francs, et les Nungovich Hotels de 1/4.

La National Bank, la Béhéra et l'action Allotment bénéficient de 1/8, l'Agricole de 3/32, la Building Landa, l'Helouan et la Levieo de 1/16, la Delta Land et la Levant de | 1/32, les Cotton Mills de 3 pence, la Salt and Soda, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail et la Port Said Salt de 6 pence, l'Aboukir de 2 shellings | 6 pence, l'obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 50 centimnes, les Lots Tores de frano, la Cassa di Sconto et la Banque d'Athènes de 12 fr. 50, le Banco di Roma de 1 fr. 50, la fondateur Allotment de 6 P.T.

La Ramleh fléchit, au contraire, de 1/16, les Privilégiées Pramways d'Alexandrie de 8-francs, les Markets de 6 pence, l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 1 franc, l'Anglo-American Nile de 1/16, le Comptoir Financier de 1/32 ainsi que l'United Land.

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changements à signaler. Du reste, comme nous l'avons fait remarquer plas haut, les oscillations constatées n'ont pas grande valeur poisqu'elles ont en général été déterminées par des offres on des demandes sans résultat appréciable.

div.head: NOS VALEURS SUR LES MARCHES EUROPPENS
div.p: Nos valeurs sont admirablement tenues sur les marchés européens et c'est sans doute à cette cause autant qu'à la baisse du taux d'escompte qu'il faut attribuer l'allure indefinissable du marché de cette semaine, qui est en hausse malgré un sentiment local de lourdeur et de fatigue.
Au Stock Exchange, l'Unifiée avance de 1 livre, la Daïra de 5/8, et la National bank de 1/4. L'Agricole et la Delta Light demenrent sans changement.
A Paris de Crédit Poneier Egyptien gagne 5 francs, la Land Bank 7 francs, la Banque d'Athènes 4 francs et le Crédit Franeo-Egyptien 3 francs 50.
D'autre part, les fonds d'Etat sont en hausse, le Consolidé Anglais de 3/4 de livre et la Rente Française de 70 points.

div.head: LA SITUATION MONETAIRE
div.p: Sans nons arrêter à la situation locale qui reste à peu près stationnaire, elle semblait avoir passé par tme phase d'amélioration en Angleterre, lorsque sondain une dépêche est venue nous annoncer qu'en raison de la demande persistante d'oren Amérique, la Banque d'Angleterre se trouvait dans l'impossibilité pour le moment de réduire son taux d'escompte. En tous cas, le taux privé a diminué de 14% depuis vendredi dernier. Grâce à son taux elevé, la Banque d'Angleterre a pu maintenir sa réserve et même l'augmenter de 11,8% dans le courapt de cette semaine ; elle est actuellement de 44 % contre 38 7/8 vendredi passé.

L'exode des ouvriers continue à New York d'od 69,000 personnes se sont embarquées pour l'Enrope la semaine dernière faute de travail en Amérique. Le message da Président Roosevelt a contribué à une reprise à Wall-Street ; il préconise l'émission de bons assez taxés pour obliger à leur rachat, dès que la crise sera passée, ainsi que le controle fédéral des corpo rations. 1,500,000 dollars ont été retenus lundi pour l'Amérique. Les banques de Chicago ont reçu une pétition signée de 2,000 banques de l'Ouest en vue de la reprise immédiate des paiements en numéraire. On croit qu'il sera obtempéré à cette requête. Les bons du Canal de Panama ont été plasieurs fois souscrits et sont cotés bien au-dessus du pair

Comme conséquence de la crise financière américaine, une banque arménienne et maison de commerce ont fait laillite A Constantinople. Son passif s'élève à £ 200.000 La Banque Otto mane est venue à son aide pour prévenir un kraob général.

Le député Luzzati, qui a été plusieurs fois ministre des finances et qui est considéré comme l'un des premiers financiers de l'Europe, & dans une étude sur la crise actnelle signale les défetaosités de système financier américain et suggéré le remède à la situation Le professeur Luzzatti propose la convocation d'une conférence internationale pour substituer à la lutte pour por un système coopératif de distribution équilibrée d'or au moyen d'accordo entre les Banques d'Etat et les trésors des divers Etats. Cette conférence examinerait et reviserait les règlements des banques d'Etat en vue de prévenir les crises financiares ou tout au moins de les atténuer. En outre, considérant que quelques Banques d'Etat Européennes échangent déjà des em prunts d'or, la conférence pourrait étudier le meilleur moyen de régler ces prêts de façon 1 permanente et dans l'intérêt général.

div.head: THE EXPERIENCE OF MANY WOMEN
div.p: Demonstrate Beyond All Cavil That Pe-ru-na Is a Safe and Useful Household Remedy.
Read What the Women Say.

Chronic Hoarseness.
Mrs Delia C. Cameron, Healdsburg, Cal., member Daughters of America, writes:
"Having tried many remedies for chronic catarrh of the bronchial tubes, and not receiving any benefit, I began to think there was no help for me until I began to use Peruna.
"In a short time the bronchial tubes began to clear, I did not have that "frog in my throat' continually, my voice was not nearly so husky, and the wheezing noise disappeared.
"I was soon able to believe that I was entirely free from catarrh, and as this was several months ago, I do not believe that it will return."
The above group of women could be maltiplied by ten thousand without reaching the number that have been helped by taking Peruna.
Catarrh of the stomach.
Miss Emily Koch, 914 Michigan Ave., Sheboygan, Wis., writes:
"I can heartily recommend Perunal for catarrh of the stomach. I had tried many things which did me no good and as last resort I got a bottle of Peruna.
"I only regret that I did not try it before I forced so much bad stuff into my stomach. It has entirely cured me and as a preventative I always keep a bottle in the house.
"I gladly recommend it to all who are afflicted as I was.”
Bronchial Catarrh.
Mrs. Wm. Hohmann, 560 N. Paulina St., Chicago, Ill., writes :
"I suffered with catarrh of the bronchial tubes and had a terrible cough ever since a child. When a child it was supposed to be whooping cough or the croup, but as I got older it got worse.

"After a while it got so bad I had to cough both winter and summer. Finally I burst a blood vessel in my throat from the strain of conghing, next a blood vessel in my stomach, so I kept getting worse and doctoring, and even then could get no relief.

"I went to a dispensary for trestment, but it all done me no good. At night I could never lie on my back. I would sit up until two or three o'clock in the morning before I could close my eyes. Then of course, I thonght, and everybody else that I had consumption.

"Reading the papere about Porus I decided to try it without the least hope that it would do me any good. But after taking three bottles I noticed a change. My appetite got better, so I kept on, never got discouraged.
"Now I can lie on my back and sleep all night, and you may well think how thankful I am for Peruna."
A Wasting Disease
Mrs. Roxa Tyler, 6210 Madison Avenue, Chtesgo, m., Vice President of the Illinois Woman's Alliance, writes:
"During the past year I gradually lost flesh and strength until I was unable to perform my work properly. I tried different remedies, and finally Peruna was suggested to me.
"It gave me new life and restored my strength. I cannot speak too highly of it."

div.head: United Hotels of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary Meeting of the UNITED HOTELS OF EGYPT, LIMITED, will be held at the Office of the Company in Egypt, No. 21 Rue Emad-el-Dine, Cairo, on MONDAY, the 23rd day of December 1907. at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. when the subjoined resolutions which were passed at the adjourned Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company held on the 5th day of December 1907, will be submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions :
(1) That the Company be wound up voluntarily.
(2) That Mr. Adolph Cattani and Mr. Jean Joannides be and are hereby appointed liquidators for the purposes of such winding-up at a remuneration of £150 each.

(3) That the said liquidators be and are hereby authorised as soon as they conveniently can out of the assets of the Company after providing for all liabilities, to return the sum of six shillings per share in respect of each ordinary share in the Company's capital upon which the sum of ten shillings has been paid up, and to return in respect of each ordinary share in the Company's capital upon which the sum of five shillings only has been paid up the sum of one shilling per share less interest on the five shillings due in respect of such share at the rate of nine per cent. per annum from the 5th day of April, 1907, to the date when the resolution for winding-up shall be confirmed.

(4) That without prejudice to the general powers vested in the said liquidators for winding-up the Company they be and are hereby especially authorised to sell the lands and properties of the Company and at such time or times at such price and on such terms and conditions as they shall in their absolute discretion think fit.
Dated this 5th day of December, 1907.
By Order of the Board,
NORMAN MORRISON,
31485-1 Secretary in Egypt

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
div.p: AVIS

Les porteurs des certificats provisoires aux nouvelles actions de Jouissance émises en Juin 1907 sont informés que le solde de la souscription, soit Frs. 90. ou P.T. 347,175 par action est payable le 1er Janvier 1908.

Les versements devront être effectués au Caire, au siège de la Société, Avenue de Boulaq ou à Alexandrie au Guichet du Crédit Lyonnais on, en meme temps, les certificats provisoires seront changés contre les titres définitifs.
En cas de retard dans les versements, il y aura lieu de plein droit à l'application de l'article II des statuts ainsi conçu :
Art. II. - A défaut de versement aux époques déterminées, l'intérêt court de plein droit à la charge de l'aetionnaire, à raison de six pour cent par an, pour chaque jour de retard.
Le retardataire est mis en demeure d'effectuer ses paiements par un avis inséré dans un des journaux désignés à l'article 8; cet avis indique les numéros des actions en retard

Faute par l'actionnaire de se libérer dans le délai d'un mois, et sans qu'il soit nécessaire de recourir à aucune formalité de justice, ni d'ajouter à ce laps d'un mois aucun délai en raison des distances, les actions en retard seront vendues publiquement sur duplicata, dans la forme qu'indiquera le Conseil d'Administration, le tout sans préjudice du droit que la Société conserve de poursuivre personnellerpent l'actionnaire en retard.

Les titres primitifs des actions ainsi vendues sont nuls de plein droit. En conséquence toute action qui ne porte pas la mention régulière des versements qui ont da être opérés, cesse d'être admissible à la négociation et au transfert.
Le Directeur,
Agrley P. FRIEND
Le Caire, le 5 Décembre 1907.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Spinning & Weaving Co. Ld.
div.p: Ordinary Coneral Meeting.

Notice is hereby given that the Ordinary General Meeting of the Shareholders of this Company will be held on the 31st day of December 1907 at 4 o'clock in the afternoon at the offices of the Company at Karmous, Alexandris, to receive the Reports of the Directors on the accounts to 30th September last, proceed to the re-election of 2 Directors retiring by rotation and to elect Auditors.

Holders of share warrants must deposit their shares to enable them to vote at the meeting, three days at least before the 31st December in one of the following banks either in Cairo or in Alexandria, National Bank of Egypt, Crédit Lyonnais, Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Imperial Ottoman Bank, Bank of Egypt or at the Company's Liverpool Offices, 7 Sweeting Street.
The Board.
Alexandria the 6th of December 1907.

div.head: Egyptian Constructions Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT AN EXTRAORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the above named Company will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel Cairo on Saturday the 21st day of December 1907 at four o'clock in the afternoon, at which the following Resolutions will be submitted,
1. That the Capital of the Company consisting of £200,000 divided into 200,000 Shares of £1 each be reduced to £132,750 divided into 265,500 Shares of ten shillings each as follows :
a) by cancelling 12,500 Shares numbered 5,001 to 7,500 and 100,001 to 110,000 each fully paid.
b) by reducing each of the 109,500 Shares numbered 1 to 5,000 750 to 100,000-110,001 to 122,000 each fully paid, from £1 to ten shillings.

2. That each of the 78,000 Shares of £1 each remaining unissued shall be divided into two shares of ten shillings each. Should the above resolutions be duly passed by the requisite majority of the same will be duly submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions to a subsequent General Meeting of the Company which will be held at the same time and place on Wednesday the 8th day of January 1908.
At the same Meeting a Resolution will be submitted by the Directors authorizing them to sell or otherwise dispose of certain portions of the businesses acquired by the Company.
Holders of bearer warrants must deposit thein at the ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK either at Cairo or Alexandria at least 48 hours before the Meeting.

Shareholders who have not taken up their bearer warrants may do so without further formality. Proxies must be left at the Company's Offices at 18 Chareh Abdeen, Cairo, at least 48 hours before the Meeting and should be in proper form.
By order of the Board.
JACKSON H. BROOKS.
Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: Ports and Lighthouse Administration

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: Societe Internationale des Employes d'Alexandrie
div.p: Siège Social Rue Sidi el Metwalli No. 30 et Rue Hammam el Zahab No. 1 au 1er Etage
BUREAU DE PLACEMENT
1 – Demoiselle très instruite donnerait à domicile des leçons de français, d'allemand et de piano.
4. - Comptable expérimenté pour les agences de Bourse cherche place. Bonnes références.
5.- Comptable correspondant accepterait place aux villages ou au Caire.
6.- Ancien employé de magasins de confection cherche place. Très bonnes références.
7 - Aide comptable d'agence de Bourse cherche place.
9. - Jeune homme, honnête et actif, connaissant bien le français et l'italien, 19 ans, cherche emploi.
10.-Jeune homme, 20 ans, initié au commerce, honnête et actif, connaissant l'italien et le français et un peu l'allemand cherche emploi.

11. - Monsieur honorablement connu écrivant le français, l'italien, l'allemand et un peu le torc, le russe et l'espagnol, comptable expert, cherche travail dans bureau. Modestes prétentions. Bonnes références.
12.- Professeur de français cherche leçons.
13.-Ancien chef de rayon d'ameublements dans une grande maison d'Europe cherche même situation en Egypte. Il parle et écrit quatre langues.
15.--Ancien employé de maison de change cherche emploi d'encaisseur ou d'aide-caissier.
16.--Monsieur connaissant parfaitement bien l'anglais et parlant 3 autres langues cherche des leçons d'anglais ou un emploi dans un bureau.
17.--- Professeur d'anglais cherche des leçons.
18.-On demande au Caire un employé chez un armurier.
N. B.— Pour tous renseignements s'adresser au Siège Social de la Société, Rue Sidi el Metwalli No. 30 et Rue Hammam el Zahab No. 1 au 1er Etage.
Le Secrétariat est ouvert tous les jours, excepté les dimanches et jours de fête, de 7 h. 1/2 à 8 h. 1/2 du soir.
Les insertions ci-dessus sont faites gratuitement par les soins de la Société et seuls le sociétaires peuvent en bénéficier.
Les personnes qui adressent des demandes à la Société, sont priées de joindre un timbre pur la réponse.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS
EMPRUNT MUNICIPAL --AMORTISSEMENT

Conformément aux avis insérés dans les journaux locaux et aux conditions spéciales réglant le tirage des titres, il a été procédé, le 2 Décembre 1907, à 5h. 1/2 p.m., an Palais Municipal, en séance poblique, au 1er tirage de 21 titres de l'Emprunt Municipal, da ler janvier 1902, et oe, en vue de leur amortissement.
Sont sortis au tirage, les numéros suivants to. No, 269 des titres de L.E. 500.
Ces titres seront remboursés, au pair, le le Janvier 1908, par la National Bank of Egypt à Alexandrie, au Caire et à Londres. Alexandrie, le 3 Décembre 1907.
L'Administrateur,
W. P. CHATAWAY. 31449-8-3
